description.narrative:
Plan International Sverige har ansökt om finansiering av egeninsats om 3 540 437 SEK för ECHO-projektet "Responding to the urgent education and protection needs of children and adolescent boys and girls affected by the conflict in Northeast Nigeria" under perioden 2018-2020.
Insatsen syftar till att ge flickor och pojkar i åldrarna 6-17 år i nordöstra Nigeria tillgång till relevant formell och icke-formell utbildning i en humanitär kontext och skydd mot våld, exploatering och försummelse genom förebyggande och responsbaserade aktiviteter.
Insatsen har en total budget på 2 941 176 EUR, vilket motsvarar cirka 31 764 701 SEK. Sökt stöd från Sida är 3 540 437 SEK, vilket motsvarar cirka 9 procent av den totala budgeten.

Plan International Sverige has applied to Sida for funding of 3 540 437 SEK to carry out the ECHO-project "Responding to the urgent education and protection needs of children and adolescent boys and girls affected by the conflict in Northeast Nigeria" during the period 2018-2020.
The purpose of the action is to provide girls and boys between the ages of 6-17 in Northeast Nigeria access to relevant formal and non-formal learning opportunities in a humanitarian context and protection aganinst violence, abuse, exploitation and neglect through prevention and response activities.
The contribution's total budget is 2 941 176 EUR, corresponding to approximately 31 764 701 SEK. The requested support from Sida is 3 540 437 SEK, which corresponds to approximately 9 per cent of the total budget.

Principal objective: Girls and boys affected by the crisis in Northeast Nigeria access quality, relevant formal and non-formal learning opportunities in emergencies contexts and are protected from violence, abuse, exploitation and neglect through prevention and response activities Specific objective: Girls and boys have increased access to quality formal and non-formal learning opportunities and live in a protective environment in which children, families and communities have skills, knowledge and behaviours to identify risks, and prevent and respond to protection concerns in Borno State Nigeria. Result 1: Targeted boys and girls ages 6-17 years access quality, relevant formal primary and secondart education learning opportunities. Result 2: Targeted girls and boys aged 9 - 17 years access quality, relevant nonformal learning opportunities Result 3: At-risk girls and boys have access to school- and community-based child protection prevention and response services and psychosocial support.

description.narrative: Nedan följer exempel på uppnådda resultat: Removing barriers to education "The action addressed a range of barriers to attending school by providing access to safe learning environments, distributing relevant school-material to children and sanitary kits to adolescent girls. As part of the action 70 Temporary Learning Spaces where rehabilitated and/or constructed, 2000 3-seater desks were provided, 80 gender segregated latrines where completed, 12 000 learning kits (6 598 girls, 5 402 boys) where distributed and 3,500 adolescent girls received sanitary kits". Quality education "The action supported training of formal and informal teachers to ensure quality of education for children in the targeted areas of Borno state. This included: training to a total of 100 formal volunteer teachers (78 male & 22 female), 60 mentor teachers (56 male & 4 female) and 90 Accelerated Learning Program (ALP) volunteer teachers/facilitators (59 male & 31 female). Training-sessions included; pedagogy, lesson preparation and planning, teachers’ code of conduct in emergencies, participatory teaching methodologies and multi-grade teaching, children’s rights and the issue of child abuse. In addition, 45 education managers (41 male & 4 female) were trained on Quality Assurance and 19 schools received teacher kits containing relevant material for a class room". Protection for at risk children "Child protection was addressed through a range of activities addressing relevant functions knowledge of risks and response, the physical environment and psychosocial support. For example: - a total of 250 teachers (193 males and 57 females) and 313 School Based Management Committee (SBMC) members (212 males and 101 females) received a one-day training on child safeguarding and prevention of sexual exploitation and abuse. - 8 Child Friendly Spaces were constructed/better equipped to support a total of 4,543 children. CFS is a key strategy to provide a safe, protective environment for children living in crisis affected areas. The CFSs were also used as points of contact for the identification and referral of children in need of case management services or referral to other services". Exempel på resultat kopplade till Strategin för stöd genom svenska organisationer i det civila samhället 2016-2020: School Based Management Committee (SBMC) "19 SBMCs (212 male & 101 female members) were supported with training on; how to organise a SBMC (purpose, setting goals, roles and responsibilities); school monitoring; child friendly schools; school development plans (including ensuring women’s involvement); resource/community mobilization for schools and the importance of education, especially the girl's education. It should be noted that the SBMCs are voluntary but established by the Government to act as a bridge between schools and the communities they serve. The SBMCs are made up of community members - women group representatives, youth leaders, local community leaders and religious leaders. The school head teacher is the secretary of the SBMC. Members are nominated and elected by the community members. The SMBC is an important meeting place for local civil society actors to come together and influence education policy and delivery for the benefit of the rights holders". Community Based Child Protection Committees (CBCPC) "20 CBCPC’s were established and strengthened through trainings and regular technical support. The CBCPCs served as frontline community support in the identification of protection concerns including out-of-school children as well as referral of at-risk children. The CBCPC has advocated for and facilitated enrolment of out-of-school children. The CBCPC play an important role in the protection of children ensuring a protective environment for children beyond the project duration".
